narratives.question_text: If a requirement, did this course occur in proper sequence within the School's educational program?  If not, where should it occur?
comments: It should occur in the the 1st year second semester to give students an opportunityto explore areas of personal interest earlier.

this was a requirement but i think it would be better if this were taught either first or second semester instead of 3rd. It would be a great class to take that could possibly spark interest in something which could develop into a thesis but the current order of this class means that we are taking it too late to do that.

I believe that it would be more beneficial if this coursewas offered in the first year of the program (either the first term or more preferably the second). It would than provide an opportunity for the post-pro students to structure their further education at Yale.
It should actually happen a little earlier in the post-pro program. probably secondsemester would be best.
The course occur in a proper sequence within the educational program. It might be even more useful if it happens in the second term of the program, instead of the third.

In class we discussed the location of this class within the post-pro sequence. Itwas the group consensus that it should be located in the first or second semester of first year. This class would be a great opportunity for students to establish a thesis proposal or focus area for their education.

As we discussed in the final session, it seems that this course would be most effective in the first semester of the March II sequence. It would provide the opportunity for students to identify a specific interest around which they could a) tailor the selection of elective credits and studios over the following three semesters b) propose a thesis or independent study.

No - This is a great introduction course for the Post-Professional program, but itshould definitely be the first required elective you take, not the last one. The course gives you an open format to explore an aspect of urbanism or architectural design that interests you. Youre able to develop your own area of concentration within this elective, which has the potential to setup a strong set of options for Post-Pro students over the course of two years if its provided at the beginning.If this light open-format elective replaced Eberharts aggressive fabrication elective in the first semester, it would work as a catalyst for a multitude of Post-Pro improvements. Post-pro students would be able gain traction within a good intro studio and elective package instead of being bombarded with Ebertharts heavy three credit elective and dividing their time between two mini-studios of lukewarm production. Eberharts class could turn into a full fledge 2nd semester building project studio for the Post Pro program, which would also resolve the programs 2nd semester dilemma when it comes to portfolio review and advanced design studio schedules. In the end, these moves would give Post-Pro students the proper footing to build up their interests and eventually opt to enter the advance studios in the second year or a final thesis setup.And finally, I believe having this entry urbanism seminar at the beginning will also help catch students who have a strict pre-conceived notion about urbanism before they try to force their ideals and interests on other students within a studio environment or future electives.

narratives.question_text: Comment on the body of material presented and the content of the course: sequence, syllabus, and assignments.
comments: the sequence of the course is pretty basic and just involves students presenting their ideas every week. I don't see how this could be any different
a very open ended, discussion based class. subjects were brought up by students, and discussed collectively.
course was very helpful and allowed individual exploration, very intersting to see other students works and I found this very encouraging to apply this knowlege to future practice and studies
The sequence and assignment is well sequenced, but the workload can be more intense during some moments of the semester.
It was interesting to see the variety and breadth of subjects which everyone chose to develop.
Great Intro Material - Structure

narratives.question_text: What were your expectations for this course and how well were they met?
comments: I had no expectations for the course but generally enjoyed it. Fred is a great teacher and I really enjoyed being able to see him every week.
I had no actual expectations, but i was finally well impressed by my classmates personal investigations and availability for mutal critique.
very good and seems to be a good course to encourage exploration as well as this is seems to be why a student would come back to grad school, to take courses like this one.
The course covered well my expectation of understanding my main area of interest, narrowing the scope in this project to undertake a feasible research, doing the research and arriving to conclusions.

I hoped to research a theme which framed this two-year course of study in relation to broader issues and trends. Although I was unable to draw the conclusions / complete the synthesis that I had originally hoped, the research was tremendously interesting and provided an overview which I will continue to reference in the future.
Good Intro Class That Met Expectations

narratives.question_text: Comment on the value of this course to you.
comments: Incredibly high. I enjoyed the opportunity for independant research very much.

This course was a fun one to take and inspired me to think about what is important to me architectural. Fred is a great educator and I learned a lot from him- not just the week i presented by topic but every week because of his great expanse of knowledge and excitement.
The course was useful because it gave me the chance to research in depth information on a topic that I have always been interested in.
it gave me the chance to bring my ongoing research further. It was valuable to me.
very high and very helpful in encouraging academic research
The course was valuable for my education.

This was a great course both in terms of learning from classmates and fred. It was a great opportunity to talk about the issues that were of interest to each student. The format of the course promoted these discussions in a wide range of topic areas.
Again, it was a luxury to do the type of research that I did. For me, the research process and exposure to the archives was invaluable.
Very High

narratives.question_text: Comment on the effectiveness of the teaching by the courses's instructor
comments: Fred did a great job. Our TA was good too although he really didn't have to do anything.
Fred was of good inspiration and really helpful for personal research and general discussion. Always available with self commitment for tutoring students' team and individual purposes.
fred was very helpful in assisting student in making their research robust and effective.
The teaching by prof Koetter was effective and stimulating for many students.
Both instructor and TA worked very well together.

Fred was able to tease-out interesting potential in every presentation. His comments following each were always relevant and insightful, often surprising.He seemed genuinely interested in all of the research, and encouraged diverse research themes and methods.
Very Effective

narratives.question_text: Suggestions you may have for course improvements:
comments: I think the only way to improve this class would be to teach it earlier in our program and not the second to last semester.

Make it happen earlier in the program: this is a perfect environment to focus on personal interests and sift through theoretical issues to bring forward in the theory class (currently happening on second semester) and finalize with an independent study or a thesis project during the last semester.
A deadline for the paper dafts a month before the final presentation might help to organize the workload.
Move course to first or second semester in first year. Inform incoming students of the role and value of this course so they can begin to think of their topics of study.
-see above (q 3)
See Answer to Question 3
